events.title: Birth of J. P. Morgan
events.description: J. P. Morgan was born in Hartford, Connecticut

events.title: Junius Spencer Morgan settles in England
events.description: Junius Spencer Morgan settled in England and lived there for the remainder of his life

events.title: J. P. Morgan establishes his own company
events.description: In 1860 Morgan set up his own company, leveraging business from his father in London and opportunities in New York

events.title: J. P. Morgan marries Amelia Sturges
events.description: In 1861 he married Amelia Sturges, who was in the advanced stages of tuberculosis

events.title: J. P. Morgan becomes a widower
events.description: Morgan returned to the United States as a widower in 1862 after failing to cure his wife's tuberculosis

events.title: Formation of J. P. Morgan and Company, Bankers
events.description: In 1862, he formed a partnership with his cousin, Jim Goodwin, and called the firm J. P. Morgan and Company, Bankers

events.title: Morgan takes in new partners and reorganizes as Dabney, Morgan and Company
events.description: Morgan spent that part of the war that followed his short-lived first marriage in making money as rapidly as he could. In September 1864 he took in new partners and reorganized as Dabney, Morgan and Company.

events.title: Morgan marries Frances Tracy
events.description: In 1865 he married Frances Tracy, one of the six daughters of attorney Charles Tracy.

events.title: Morgan and his wife tour California
events.description: In the summer of 1869, Morgan and his wife, accompanied by two relatives, rode the new transcontinental railroad to Utah and to California, where they toured extensively by stagecoach and horseback.

events.title: Morgan considers retiring
events.description: In 1871, troubled by nervous disorders, Morgan briefly considered retiring.

events.title: Morgan lends money to U.S. Army
events.description: In the summer of 1877, Morgan lent the U.S. Army money to pay its troops after Congress had adjourned without setting aside the money.

events.title: Morgan sells William Vanderbilt's shares of New York Central Railroad
events.description: In 1879 he performed a more sedate but much more lucrative feat in selling William Vanderbilt's 250,000 shares of New York Central Railroad stock (87 percent of those in existence) without suffering any depreciation (loss in value) or inciting anyone to try to displace the railroad's management.

events.title: The year of enormous challenge and profit
events.description: The year 1880 brought another enormous challenge, converted into enormous profits.

events.title: Selling of $40 million in bonds for the Northern Pacific
events.description: In 1880, there was an enormous challenge of selling $40 million in bonds for the Northern Pacific, a transcontinental that had suffered bankruptcy and reorganization in the Panic of 1873.

events.title: Morgan builds a home at 219 Madison Avenue
events.description: Morgan built a home at 219 Madison Avenue in 1881 which he later used to house his collection of rare manuscripts and books.

events.title: Morgan starts collecting art
events.description: Morgan began buying rare and old works of art on an immense scale after the death of his father.

events.title: Saving the U.S. Treasury's gold reserve
events.description: In 1893, Morgan had to form a syndicate of American and European bankers to stop the flow of gold from the Treasury out of the country.

events.title: Formation of U.S. Steel Corporation
events.description: In 1901, Morgan formed the United States Steel Corporation, the world's first billion-dollar corporation.

events.title: Antitrust prosecution of Northern Pacific and Great Northern merger
events.description: In 1904, the government won the lawsuit against the merger of the Northern Pacific railroad with its regional rival, the Great Northern, contending that the combination would be too powerful and in violation of antitrust law.

events.title: Morgan prevents a financial panic
events.description: In 1907, Morgan led a syndicate of bankers to prevent a financial panic.

events.title: Morgan summoned before the Pujo Committee
events.description: In 1912, Morgan was summoned before the Pujo Committee, which charged him with controlling all the large banks, railroads, and steel companies of the United States through interlocking directorships and stockholdings.

events.title: Death of J. P. Morgan
events.description: J. P. Morgan died in Rome, Italy

events.title: Death of Morgan in Rome
events.description: Morgan died during one of his periods of travel in Rome, Italy.

events.title: Publication of Merchants and Masterpieces: The Story of the Metropolitan
events.description: The book by E. P. Dutton was published.

events.title: Publication of UXL Biographies
events.description: The book titled 'UXL Biographies' was published by UXL.

events.title: Access of J. P. Morgan document
events.description: The document titled 'J. P. Morgan' was accessed.
